newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Southern Africa plans meeting on Angola peace.
newsitem.headline: Southern Africa plans meeting on Angola peace.

text.p: Southern African presidents may call a meeting with Angolan leaders to try and break the deadlock holding up the war-torn country's peace process, Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe said on Tuesday.

Mugabe told reporters after a three-hour meeting by five Southern African Development Community (SADC) leaders in Harare that the region was concerned at the slow progress in implementation of a peace deal the Angolan government and the former UNITA rebel movement signed in Lusaka, Zambia, in 1994.
"We want to try and find a way to break the present impasse," Mugabe, chairman of a SADC unit set up to ensure peace in the region, said.
"There is a possibility of organising a meeting to be attended by both parties, government and UNITA. We are looking at that possibility," he said.

The meeting -- which was held on the sidelines of the two-day World Solar Summit which ended in Harare on Tuesday -- was attended by Mugabe, Botswana's Ketumile Masire, Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania, Frederick Chiluba of Zambia and Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, as well as Angolan Prime Minister Franca van Dunem.
Earlier in the day, van Dunem told the conference that although his country had ended its 20-year civil war, it was far from enjoying peace and stability.

"In spite of the expectations, the peace process is yet to become a reality. We live in a state of no peace and no war," van Dunem said, accusing Jonas Savimbi's UNITA of lacking commitment to the Lusaka agreements.
The southern African country's situation has been precarious for the past two years, with the two sides trading accusations of holding up the United Nations-supervised peace process.
Last Friday, UNITA's secretary-general Paulo Gato said the government of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos was delaying talks to prepare a summit between him and Savimbi.
